docs.snippet: The killing of Archbishop Isaías Duarte Cancino of Cali, Colombia, on Saturday night, after he officiated over a group wedding in a poor neighborhood, stunned a country already deep in conflict.    The outspoken Roman Catholic archbishop, who had...
docs.lead_paragraph: The killing of Archbishop Isaías Duarte Cancino of Cali, Colombia, on Saturday night, after he officiated over a group wedding in a poor neighborhood, stunned a country already deep in conflict. The outspoken Roman Catholic archbishop, who had often been critical of the country's leftist rebels, was shot by two men as he headed to his car outside a church in Cali.
docs.abstract: Assassination of Archbishop Isaias Duarte Cancino of Cali, Colombia, after officiating over group wedding in poor neighborhood, stuns country already deep in conflict; Colombian law enforcement officials hint rebels are most likely responsible, while church officials say narcotics traffickers may have killed him; his excommunication of rebels for kidnapping civilians and his castigation of drug-tainted candidates in recent congressional elections noted; his involvement in country's civil war and his help in arranging secret meetings between government officials and outlawed rightist paramilitary group responsible for thousands of killings discussed; government offers $483,000 reward for information leading to arrest of killers; thousands show up at Cali's cathedral to pay respects; he is mourned by Pope John Paul II, who issues statement lauding him as generous and valiant pastor; photo (M)

headline.main: Rebels or Drug Rings Suspected in Colombian Prelate's Killing

docs.snippet: As the first human rights official to inspect the American military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, Urs Boegli was expecting a frosty, even hostile, reception.     At the time, President Bush had refused to grant the men captured in the Afghan wa...
docs.lead_paragraph: As the first human rights official to inspect the American military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, Urs Boegli was expecting a frosty, even hostile, reception. At the time, President Bush had refused to grant the men captured in the Afghan war protection under the Geneva Conventions -- the accords at the heart of Mr. Boegli's authority to ensure that the men flown to the Cuban base were being treated humanely. But European countries were openly questioning the American military's handling of the detainees, from blindfolding and sedating them to holding them in metal cages.
docs.abstract: Interview with Urs Boegli of International Committee of the Red Cross, who was first human rights official to inspect American military prison at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, where suspected Al Qaeda terrorists captured in Afghanistan are being detained; says he has been welcomed by American soldiers in Guantanamo as 'a necessary annoyance;' photo (M)

headline.main: Red Cross Man in Guantánamo: A 'Busybody,' but Not Unwelcome

docs.snippet: The former king, Mohammed Zahir Shah, plans to return to Kabul around March 21 and plans to stay in his homeland, said his personal physician, Dr. Zalmai Rasul. Zahir Shah, 87, is seen as a possibly major unifying force in Afghanistan after decade...
docs.lead_paragraph: The former king, Mohammed Zahir Shah, plans to return to Kabul around March 21 and plans to stay in his homeland, said his personal physician, Dr. Zalmai Rasul. Zahir Shah, 87, is seen as a possibly major unifying force in Afghanistan after decades of fighting by rival factions and the overthrow of the Taliban.
docs.abstract: Ex-King Mohammed Zahir Shah reportedly will return to Afghanistan around Mar 21 and plans to stay in his homeland (S)

docs.snippet: In the first major expansion of the war on terrorism, American and Philippine military officers in Manila began preparing joint operations today against a Muslim extremist group linked to Al Qaeda in the southern Philippines.    More than 600 Amer...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the first major expansion of the war on terrorism, American and Philippine military officers in Manila began preparing joint operations today against a Muslim extremist group linked to Al Qaeda in the southern Philippines. More than 600 American troops, including 160 Special Operations forces trained in counterterrorism, are expected to be sent this month to train and advise 1,200 Philippine Army soldiers in how to destroy Abu Sayyaf, a terrorist group that is holding hostages, including two Americans.
docs.abstract: United States and Philippines, in first major expansion of war on terrorism, prepare joint operations against Abu Sayyaf, Muslim extremist group in southern Philippines linked to Al Qaeda; US plans to send over 600 troops, including 160 Special Operations forces trained in counterterrorism, to Mindanao to train and advise 1,200 Philippine Army soldiers in how to destroy group, which is holding hostages; US forces will accompany patrols in rebel areas, authorized to fire only in self-defense; Sec Donald H Rumsfeld outlines plan (M)

headline.main: U.S. and Philippines Setting Up Joint Operations to Fight Terror

docs.snippet: Standing with his soldiers on the second floor of Mirvais Hospital here, Nazer Jan said at least some of the six men believed to be Al Qaeda fighters trapped on the other side of a sealed doorway at the end of the corridor were still alive, despit...
docs.lead_paragraph: Standing with his soldiers on the second floor of Mirvais Hospital here, Nazer Jan said at least some of the six men believed to be Al Qaeda fighters trapped on the other side of a sealed doorway at the end of the corridor were still alive, despite attempts to starve them out. ''At night we can hear them reciting the Koran,'' said Mr. Jan, who leads a squad of a dozen men, armed with machine guns, who guard the corridor in case the fighters try to break free. He said the pattern of nightly prayer suggested that the men were following a religious regimen that included fasting during the day.
docs.abstract: Six armed men believed to be Al Qaeda fighters who barracaded selves in Kandahar, Afghanistan, hospital resist ongoing effort to starve them out; soldiers who guard corridor to bar their escape are also suspected of passing them supplies; men's supporters demonstrate outside Gov Gul Agaha Shirzai's compound; photo (M)

headline.main: Captives Remain Holed Up in Kandahar Hospital Drama

docs.snippet: After touring the shattered capital of Afghanistan and talking to its temporary leaders, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Joseph R. Biden Jr., said today that the United States should take part in a multinational military fo...
docs.lead_paragraph: After touring the shattered capital of Afghanistan and talking to its temporary leaders, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Joseph R. Biden Jr., said today that the United States should take part in a multinational military force to restore order to this country. ''I'm not talking about blue helmets,'' Mr. Biden said, referring to a United Nations-style peacekeeping mission. ''I'm talking about a multilateral force with orders to shoot to kill. Absent that, I don't see any hope for this country.''
docs.abstract: Sen Joseph R Biden Jr, Senate committee head, tours Kabul and meets with Afghanistan's acting leader, Hamid Karzi, and other top officials; holds United States should take part in multinational military force empowered to shoot to kill to restore order in nation; notes interim government needs immediate funds; Defense Department reports small but steady stream of Army troops are arriving at Kandahar airport to relieve marines who secured airport; photo (M)

headline.main: Biden Wants U.S. Troops to Join Peace Force

docs.snippet: Gul Agha Shirzai was the governor of Kandahar Province in the early 1990's, an infamous period filled with anarchy that was shocking even by Afghan standards. Gul Agha was personally acquainted with the ethos of those times. In 1989, his father, w...
docs.lead_paragraph: Gul Agha Shirzai was the governor of Kandahar Province in the early 1990's, an infamous period filled with anarchy that was shocking even by Afghan standards. Gul Agha was personally acquainted with the ethos of those times. In 1989, his father, who had joined the jihad after the Soviet invasion in 1979 and became a respected commander and Pashtun tribal leader, was murdered by a cook who slipped arsenic into his lunch. Avenging the crime, Gul Agha tied the cook to a tree, shot him with a Kalashnikov and hung his shredded corpse from a branch for a week. When the United States government went shopping last fall for someone to lead an army into the Taliban stronghold of Kandahar, Gul Agha re-emerged as America's go-to warlord. He had spent seven years in luxurious exile in Pakistan, waiting for a chance to get rid of the black-turbaned Taliban mullahs who'd gotten rid of him. In early November, he slipped into Afghanistan with a ragtag army of 1,500 Afghan fighters and joined up in the border village of Shinarai with a honed unit of a dozen or so American Special Forces soldiers who arrived in helicopters at night. In the days that followed, weapons arrived after dark, too, falling to earth in wood crates shoved from the bellies of American military aircraft. The crates, attached to parachutes, contained Kalashnikov assault rifles, serrated steel bayonets and rocket-propelled grenades, and they were collected outside Shinarai by the Special Forces troops who gave them to Gul Agha.
docs.abstract: Peter Maass article on return to Afghanistan of former Kandahar governor Gul Agha Shirzai, warlord exiled by Taliban; holds Afghanistan is in hands of veteran warlords like him who know and care more about power and money than about human rights or civil society; sees them treating nominal leader, Hamid Karzai, chosen at behest of United States officials, as little more than delivery boy for aid checks from West; photos (M)

headline.main: Gul Agha Gets His Province Back

docs.snippet: A picture caption on Dec. 5 about helicopters at a Marine base in Afganistan misidentified several of them, and a correction in this space last Monday also misstated a type.  The twin-rotor helicopter on the ground at the left was a Marine Corps C...
docs.lead_paragraph: A picture caption on Dec. 5 about helicopters at a Marine base in Afganistan misidentified several of them, and a correction in this space last Monday also misstated a type. The twin-rotor helicopter on the ground at the left was a Marine Corps CH-46E Sea Knight; it was neither a CH-53 nor a Chinook, which is designated CH-47 and is the Army version of the Sea Knight. Only the craft at the right was a CH-53. While two of the craft in the air were correctly identified as Super Cobra attack helicopters, the third was a Huey UH-1.
docs.abstract: Correction of Dec 5 picture caption and Dec 10 correction which misidentified helicopters at Marine base in Afghanistan
docs.section_name: Corrections; Washington; New York and Region

docs.snippet: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld painted an uncertain future today for the hundreds of prisoners of the Afghan war being held in Cuba, saying they might be returned to their own countries or might be held indefinitely to keep them from pick...
docs.lead_paragraph: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld painted an uncertain future today for the hundreds of prisoners of the Afghan war being held in Cuba, saying they might be returned to their own countries or might be held indefinitely to keep them from picking up arms again. The United States could hold them ''during the period of the conflict so that they can't go back and kill more people,'' Mr. Rumsfeld said.
docs.abstract: Sec Donald Rumsfeld says hundreds of prisoners of Afghan war now being held in Cuba may be returned to own countries or held indefinitely to keep them from picking up arms again; says Pentagon is close to drawing up final rules for military tribunals; 300 men from 26 countries are now in detention (M)

headline.main: Rumsfeld Lists Outcomes For Detainees Held in Cuba

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The issue of mistreatment of the prisoners incarcerated at Guantánamo Bay has included descriptions of bug-infested quarters, terrible meals, facilities without adequate plumbing and the like (front page, Jan. 23). This could al...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The issue of mistreatment of the prisoners incarcerated at Guantánamo Bay has included descriptions of bug-infested quarters, terrible meals, facilities without adequate plumbing and the like (front page, Jan. 23). This could also describe my experience at Fort Benning, Ga., as an Army reservist called up for the Bosnian conflict.
docs.abstract: Letter from Gordon Tagge says descriptions of bug-infested quarters at Guantanamo Bay could also describe his experience at Fort Benning, Ga, as Army reservist (Jan 23 article)
